Great question — here's a straight answer:

💡 Is this job easier than coding with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript?

Yes and no. Here's a breakdown:

✅ Easier in Some Ways:

  • You don’t need to code everything from scratch.

    • Elementor is a drag-and-drop builder, so most layout and styling can be done visually.

  • Faster to build pages.

    • You can quickly create sections, columns, and animations without writing code.

  • Less JavaScript.

    • Most motion effects are built-in — no need to write custom JavaScript unless advanced effects are needed.

❌ Harder in Other Ways:

  • You must match designs exactly (pixel-perfect).

    • Even if it looks “close,” the client may ask you to fix 1px issues.

  • You’re expected to be creative with animations and responsiveness.

    • You won’t always get step-by-step instructions — they expect you to make it look great on your own.

  • You must know how WordPress works.

    • Themes, plugins, Elementor quirks, responsive breakpoints — these can be tricky if you’re new to it.

  • You may still use custom CSS or even HTML inside Elementor to tweak things.

🧠 So, what’s the bottom line?

If you're comfortable with HTML/CSS/JavaScript, then Elementor will feel easier in most cases — like using power tools instead of hand tools. But you still need a strong eye for design, speed, and accuracy.

You said:
what is eslementor?
ChatGPT said:

Elementor is a drag-and-drop page builder plugin for WordPress that lets you build websites visually — without needing to write code (though you still can if you want to).

🔧 What Elementor Does:

  • You can drag sections, columns, images, text, buttons, and more onto the page.

  • You design live on the page, like a visual editor — no switching between editor and preview.

  • It includes built-in animations, spacing controls, responsiveness, and templates.

🧱 Basic Example:

Instead of writing this HTML:

html
<div class="hero">
  <h1>Welcome</h1>
  <p>This is my site.</p>
</div>

With Elementor, you:

  1. Drag a "Section" onto the page.

  2. Add a "Heading" widget: write "Welcome"

  3. Add a "Text Editor" widget: write "This is my site."

  4. Adjust padding, fonts, colors, and animations with easy settings.

✨ Features:

  • Live Frontend Editor: See your changes instantly.

  • Responsive Design Tools: Customize for desktop, tablet, mobile.

  • Motion Effects & Animations: Scroll effects, hover animations, transitions.

  • Templates & Blocks: Start with ready-made layouts.

  • Custom CSS: You can still write your own CSS if needed.

📌 Who Uses Elementor?

  • Web developers who want to build fast without coding everything.

  • Designers who don’t know code but want to build pages.

  • Agencies that need to build and update lots of client websites quickly.

Let me know if you want a beginner-friendly Elementor tutorial or if you'd like to try building a page using it — I can walk you through it.

You said:
what is wix
ChatGPT said:

Wix is an all-in-one website builder that lets you create a website without coding, similar to Elementor — but it’s not WordPress.

🟨 What is Wix?

Wix is a hosted platform where you can:

  • Design websites using drag-and-drop

  • Add pages, text, images, galleries, videos

  • Use pre-built templates or make your own

  • Launch a site without touching code or installing anything

It's popular for small businesses, portfolios, personal websites, and online stores.

🧱 How it Works (vs Elementor):

FeatureWixElementor (WordPress)
Hosted byWixYou choose your own hosting
Drag-and-drop builder✅ Built-in✅ As a plugin
No coding needed✅ Yes✅ Yes (optional)
Custom domain✅ Yes (on paid plans)✅ Yes
Flexibility🔸 Limited🟢 More flexible
Advanced customization🔸 Harder🟢 Easier with plugins/CSS
SEO tools✅ Built-in✅ With plugins

🎨 What You Can Do With Wix:

  • Build a full website with multiple pages

  • Add animations and scroll effects

  • Create online stores (with Wix eCommerce)

  • Add bookings, forms, live chat, and more with Wix apps

⚠️ Downsides of Wix:

  • Less flexible for complex or large websites

  • Not as good for custom backend development

  • Hard to migrate your site later if you outgrow Wix

🟢 Good For:

  • Beginners who want to build fast

  • Non-coders

  • Clients who want to edit their own site later

wix and worpdress are same?
ChatGPT said:

Wix and WordPress are not the same, but they are both tools used to build websites. Here's a clear breakdown of how they differ:

🔍 Wix vs WordPress: Key Differences

FeatureWixWordPress
TypeAll-in-one website builderOpen-source CMS (Content Management System)
HostingHosting is includedYou must get your own web hosting (e.g., Bluehost, Hostinger)
Code AccessLimited accessFull access to HTML, CSS, PHP
Ease of UseEasier for beginners (drag & drop)Slightly more complex, more flexible
CustomizationLess flexibleHighly customizable with plugins & themes
CostMonthly plans (includes hosting)WordPress is free, but hosting & plugins may cost
OwnershipWix controls your site (closed system)You control everything (open source)
Plugins/AppsWix App Market (limited)59,000+ plugins available
SEO & PerformanceGood, but limited advanced SEOExcellent SEO control with right setup
eCommerceBuilt-in (Wix Stores)WooCommerce for advanced shops
ExamplesPortfolios, small businessesBlogs, company sites, complex systems

🧠 Summary:

  • Wix is like using a template-based design tool. It’s great for non-coders who want a fast, easy setup.

  • WordPress is for more control and flexibility. It's better if you want to scale or customize your website deeply.

🧩 Analogy:

Wix is like buying a furnished apartment: you move in and start using it, but can't change the structure.
WordPress is like buying an empty lot: you can build anything you want, but you need the right tools (plugins, hosting, etc.).

ChatGPT said:

Absolutely! Here's a simple and clear explanation of each item one by one — perfect for someone applying to a web developer role like the one you're considering:

✅ Know about basics of HTML

  • HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the basic structure of all web pages.

  • It defines headings, paragraphs, links, images, etc.

  • Example: <h1>Hello</h1> creates a heading.

✅ WordPress

  • A free content management system (CMS) used to build websites.

  • You install it on a web host and use themes/plugins to customize your site.

  • Used by over 40% of websites globally.

✅ Elementor

  • A visual page builder plugin for WordPress.

  • Lets you drag-and-drop elements (text, images, buttons) without writing code.

  • Great for fast, beautiful, responsive designs.

✅ WordPress Bakery (WPBakery)

  • Another WordPress page builder plugin (like Elementor).

  • Allows you to create pages using pre-made content blocks.

  • Used in some themes (especially older ones).

✅ Webflow

  • A no-code design platform to build custom websites with full HTML/CSS/JS control.

  • Popular with designers who want freedom without touching raw code.

  • Generates clean code and allows CMS-like control.

✅ Shopify

  • A hosted eCommerce platform to build online stores.

  • Includes product management, payment integration, shipping, etc.

  • Drag-and-drop friendly and easy for beginners.

✅ WooCommerce

  • A plugin for WordPress that turns a WordPress site into an online store.

  • You get full control over products, checkout, design, and features.

  • Often used by developers because it’s more customizable than Shopify.

✅ Wix

  • A hosted website builder that’s beginner-friendly and drag-and-drop based.

  • Great for small businesses or personal websites.

  • Less flexible than WordPress, but much easier for non-coders.

✅ Squarespace

  • Another website builder, like Wix.

  • Known for stylish templates and ease of use.

  • Great for portfolios, small shops, blogs, and creative businesses.

✅ Thinkific

  • A platform for creating online courses.

  • You can build lessons, quizzes, and sell access to your courses.

  • No coding needed, great for educators and coaches.

✅ LearnDash

  • A WordPress plugin that adds course-building features.

  • You install it on your WordPress site to create online learning platforms.

  • More flexible and developer-friendly than Thinkific.

✅ Kajabi Page Builder

  • A drag-and-drop tool inside Kajabi (an all-in-one platform for online businesses).

  • Used to build landing pages, course pages, checkout pages, etc.

  • Great for marketing funnels and info-product creators.

✅ Understand Sitemaps

  • A sitemap is a file that lists all the pages of your website.

  • Helps Google and other search engines crawl and index your site properly.

  • Usually found at yourdomain.com/sitemap.xml.

✅ Basic Knowledge of SQL

  • SQL (Structured Query Language) is used to communicate with databases.

  • Example: SELECT * FROM users pulls all user data.

  • WordPress uses a MySQL database, so basic SQL helps when debugging or customizing.

✅ Understand 301 vs 302 Redirects

  • 301 Redirect = Permanent move. Search engines update the old link to the new one.

  • 302 Redirect = Temporary move. Search engines don’t update the old link.

  • Used when you change page URLs to keep SEO intact.

✅ What is an SSL Certificate

  • SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) encrypts data between your website and the visitor.

  • It makes your site use https:// instead of http://.

  • It's important for security and SEO.

✅ Modular Design

  • Building a website using reusable sections or components.

  • Makes it easier to manage and update.

  • Example: A testimonial block used on 5 pages only needs to be updated once.

✅ Object-Oriented vs Procedural Programming

  • Procedural: Code runs from top to bottom, like a recipe. Functions are separate.

  • Object-Oriented: Code is organized into classes and objects. Helps with larger, reusable code.

  • WordPress core is written mostly in procedural PHP, but you can use both styles.

Let me know if you want a cheat sheet PDF version of this or if you want help improving your answers for a job application based on these!

You said:
how can i use sql in wordpress?
ChatGPT said:

Great question! In WordPress, you usually don’t need to write SQL manually, because it already handles most database operations for you through functions like get_posts(), wp_query(), update_post_meta(), etc.

But if you want to use SQL directly, here's how you can do it safely and properly.

🧠 WordPress Uses MySQL

All WordPress data (posts, users, settings, pages, etc.) is stored in a MySQL database. You can interact with this database using:

  • WordPress functions (recommended)

  • Direct SQL queries (advanced)

✅ Option 1: Using SQL with $wpdb (the correct way in WordPress)

WordPress provides a global variable called $wpdb, which lets you safely run SQL queries.

📌 Example 1: Select all posts

php
global $wpdb;
$results = $wpdb->get_results( "SELECT * FROM $wpdb->posts WHERE post_status = 'publish'" );

foreach ( $results as $post ) {
    echo $post->post_title . "<br>";
}

  • $wpdb->get_results() → Returns multiple rows.

  • $wpdb->posts → This uses the correct database prefix (e.g. wp_posts).

📌 Example 2: Insert a custom row

php
$wpdb->insert(
    'wp_custom_table',
    array(
        'name' => 'Jayvee',
        'email' => 'jayvee@example.com'
    )
);

📌 Example 3: Custom SELECT with JOIN

php
$results = $wpdb->get_results("
    SELECT p.ID, p.post_title, m.meta_value AS price
    FROM $wpdb->posts p
    JOIN $wpdb->postmeta m ON p.ID = m.post_id
    WHERE m.meta_key = '_price' AND p.post_type = 'product'
");

⚠️ Always Escape Your Queries!

To prevent SQL injection, use:

  • $wpdb->prepare()

Example:

php
$sql = $wpdb->prepare("SELECT * FROM $wpdb->users WHERE user_email = %s", $email);
$user = $wpdb->get_row($sql);

🧪 Option 2: Use a Plugin for SQL Access (Optional)

You can use plugins like:

  • WP Data Access

  • WP phpMyAdmin

  • Advanced Database Cleaner

They let you run SQL queries or manage the database visually from the WordPress dashboard.

🚫 Do NOT Edit Database Directly Without Backups

If you're running raw SQL queries:

  • Always back up your site first

  • Always test on a staging site, not live

🔧 When Should You Use SQL in WordPress?

Use SQL if:

  • You're doing custom reports

  • You're building custom plugins

  • You're debugging or migrating data

  • You need to optimize performance with complex queries

Let me know if you want to try a live example, or if you want a cheat sheet of the most common WordPress tables (wp_posts, wp_users, wp_postmeta, etc.).

  • If a plugin breaks or data isn’t showing up, you might need to check the database.

  • Example: A client says "products disappeared" — you might look into the wp_posts or wp_postmeta tables to investigate.

2. Custom Queries or Reports

  • You may need to pull custom data for clients (e.g., list of orders, users, or course enrollments).

  • Example: "Get all users who bought a course last month."

3. Advanced Page Builders / Plugins

  • Some plugins (like WooCommerce, Learndash) store complex data in the database. Understanding where and how helps when customizing.

4. Optimizing Performance

  • If a page loads slowly, maybe a plugin is making bad SQL queries. Knowing SQL helps you spot and solve that.

5. Understanding WordPress Structure

  • SQL knowledge helps you understand how posts, metadata, users, settings are all saved and connected in the database.

📝 In Short:

You don’t need to use SQL every day in this job — but having basic knowledge will:

  • Make you better at solving problems

  • Help you understand how WordPress works under the hood

  • Make you more valuable to the team

You said:
explain me the last object oriented and
ChatGPT said:

Sure! Let’s break down the last topic in the list:

🔄 Object-Oriented vs Procedural Programming

This is about how you structure your code.

🧱 1. Procedural Programming (step-by-step)

  • Think of it like a recipe: code runs from top to bottom.

  • You write functions and call them when needed.

  • Common in basic PHP and WordPress functions.

✅ Example (Procedural PHP):

php
function greet($name) {
    return "Hello, " . $name;
}

echo greet("Jayvee");

🧩 2. Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)

  • Code is organized into classes and objects (like blueprints and real items).

  • Useful for reusability, modularity, and clean structure.

  • Often used in plugins, themes, or large systems.

✅ Example (Object-Oriented PHP):

php
class Greeter {
    public function greet($name) {
        return "Hello, " . $name;
    }
}

$greeter = new Greeter();
echo $greeter->greet("Jayvee");

📌 What's the difference?

ConceptProceduralObject-Oriented
StructureCode runs top to bottomCode is organized into objects
ReuseHarder to reuseEasier to reuse with classes
ExampleWordPress core functionsWordPress plugins or themes
Use caseSimple tasksLarge, complex projects
SpeedOften fasterSlightly slower but scalable

🧠 In WordPress context:

  • WordPress itself is mostly procedural, but many plugins and themes use OOP for organization.

  • If you understand both, you’ll be able to:

    • Read plugin code

    • Customize themes better

    • Write more advanced custom features

🧠 Real-life analogy:

  • Procedural = A to-do list where you do one task after another.

  • OOP = A team of workers (objects), each with their own job (methods), that you assign tasks to.

Let me know if you want a cheat sheet on PHP OOP syntax used in WordPress plugins/themes!

.services h2{ margin-bottom: 5rem; } .services-container{ display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; flex-wrap: wrap; gap: 2rem; } .services-container .services-box{ flex: 1 1 30rem; background: var(--second-bg-color); padding: 3rem 2rem 4rem; border-radius: 2rem; text-align: center; border: .2rem solid var(--bg-color); } why the container goes to bottom not to right
ChatGPT said:

Your .services-container is set to display: flex with flex-wrap: wrap and justify-content: center, which should place child .services-box elements side by side (horizontally) and wrap them to the next line if they don’t fit.

If your boxes are stacking vertically (going to bottom) instead of side by side, here are some common reasons and fixes:

1. Parent container width might be too small

If the .services-container or its parent container is narrow, the .services-box elements can’t fit side by side, so they stack vertically.

Fix: Make sure the container has enough width or max-width to allow boxes to sit next to each other.

css
.services-container {
  max-width: 1200px; /* or any suitable width */
  margin: 0 auto;
}

2. .services-box flex-basis might be too large

You set flex: 1 1 30rem; which means each box tries to be at least 30rem wide (480px approx). If the container is narrower than 3 boxes × 30rem + gaps, they won’t fit side by side.

Fix: Reduce the flex-basis (30rem) or increase container width.

3. Check for conflicting CSS

Make sure there are no other styles or parent containers restricting layout, like display: block, fixed widths, or flex-direction: column set on .services-container or parents.

4. Use browser dev tools

Inspect .services-container and .services-box with dev tools to see actual widths, flex direction, and whether wrapping is happening.

5. Add min-width: 0 on flex children (sometimes helps)

css
.services-container .services-box {
  min-width: 0;
}

Example fix to try:

css
.services-container {
  display: flex;
  flex-wrap: wrap;
  justify-content: center;
  gap: 2rem;
  max-width: 1200px;  /* make container wider */
  margin: 0 auto;
}

.services-container .services-box {
  flex: 1 1 25rem;  /* slightly smaller */
  min-width: 250px; /* prevent shrinking too small */
  background: var(--second-bg-color);
  padding: 3rem 2rem 4rem;
  border-radius: 2rem;
  text-align: center;
  border: .2rem solid var(--bg-color);
}

ChatGPT said:

Ah, I see the issue — your images are different sizes, so they don’t line up evenly in the grid.

Here’s how to make all your images the same display size, without needing them to be the exact same original dimensions.

✅ SOLUTION: Force images to a fixed aspect ratio or height

You can control the image size by setting a fixed height and making sure it maintains aspect ratio or crops properly.

✅ Option 1: Use object-fit with fixed height

This lets you keep your layout consistent even with different image sizes.

Update your CSS like this:

css
.portfolio-box img {
    width: 100%;
    height: 250px; /* or any fixed height you want */
    object-fit: cover; /* Crop the image to fit */
    border-radius: 1rem;
}

🔹 object-fit: cover keeps the image from stretching and fills the area by cropping edges if needed.

✅ Option 2: Use a fixed aspect ratio container

For more control, wrap the <img> in a container that keeps an aspect ratio.

css
.portfolio-box {
    position: relative;
    border-radius: 2rem;
    box-shadow: 0 0 1rem var(--bg-color);
    overflow: hidden;
    display: flex;
    height: 250px; /* Set desired box height */
}
.portfolio-box img {
    width: 100%;
    object-fit: cover;
}

You said:
let sections = document.querySelectorAll('section'); let navLinks = document.querySelectorAll('header nav a'); window.onscroll = () => { sections.forEach(sec => { let top = window.scrollY; let offset = sec.offsetTop - 150; let height = sec.offsetHeight; let id = sec.getAttribute('id'); if(top >= offset && top < offset + height) { navLinks.forEach(links => { links.classList.remove('active'); document.querySelector('header nav a[href*=' +id + ']').classList.add('active'); }); }; }); }; what does this do
ChatGPT said:

That JavaScript code is used to highlight the active navigation link in your navbar based on the section currently visible on the screen as you scroll down your website.

🔍 Let's break it down:

javascript
let sections = document.querySelectorAll('section');
let navLinks = document.querySelectorAll('header nav a');

  • sections: selects all <section> elements on the page (like #home, #about, #services, etc.)

  • navLinks: selects all <a> links inside the <nav> tag in your <header>

📜 window.onscroll = () => { ... }

This runs the code every time you scroll the page.

🧠 Inside the scroll event:

javascript
sections.forEach(sec => {
    let top = window.scrollY; // how far you've scrolled from the top
    let offset = sec.offsetTop - 150; // position of the section from top of the page (with offset)
    let height  = sec.offsetHeight; // height of the section
    let id = sec.getAttribute('id'); // e.g., 'about', 'services'

This checks each section and sees:

  • Is the current scroll position (top) within the boundaries of this section?

javascript
if(top >= offset && top < offset + height) {
    // We're inside this section

✅ Then it updates the nav:

javascript
    navLinks.forEach(links => {
        links.classList.remove('active'); // Remove old active links
        document.querySelector('header nav a[href*=' + id + ']').classList.add('active');
    });

  • Removes the .active class from all nav links

  • Finds the <a> link that corresponds to the section currently in view (href*='about' if you're in the #about section)

  • Adds the .active class to it, so it gets highlighted (usually by a color or underline in your CSS)

🎯 Final Result:

When the user scrolls to #about, the About link becomes highlighted.
When they scroll to #services, the Services link gets highlighted, and so on.

Let me know if you want me to help you style the .active class in CSS for a cool effect (like a glow or underline).

You said:
how to have glow in the back of the image
ChatGPT said:

To create a glow behind an image, you can use CSS box-shadow on the image or the container of the image. Here's how you can do it:

✅ Simple Glow Behind Image

Apply this to your image:

css
img {
  box-shadow: 0 0 20px rgba(0, 255, 255, 0.6); /* soft glow */
  border-radius: 10px; /* optional, for rounded corners */
}

💡 Explanation:

  • 0 0 20px = X offset, Y offset, and blur radius.

  • rgba(0, 255, 255, 0.6) = glow color (cyan in this case) with transparency.

🌌 Cool Glow Examples

Blue glow:

css
img {
  box-shadow: 0 0 25px rgba(0, 153, 255, 0.7);
}

Purple glow:

css
img {
  box-shadow: 0 0 25px rgba(128, 0, 255, 0.7);
}

Neon green glow:

css
img {
  box-shadow: 0 0 25px rgba(0, 255, 0, 0.6);
}

🧪 You can also animate it:

css
img:hover {
  box-shadow: 0 0 35px rgba(0, 255, 255, 0.9);
  transition: box-shadow 0.3s ease;
}

Would you like me to match the glow with your portfolio's current dark + glow aesthetic? Just let me know the glow color or vibe (cyberpunk, soft, warm, etc.).

You said:
why does the image became double when i go to mobile mode
ChatGPT said:

If your image appears doubled or duplicated in mobile view, it’s likely due to one of the following issues:

🔁 1. You have duplicate image containers

Check your HTML to make sure you don’t have the same <img> tag inside two different containers that both show on mobile.

✅ Fix: Ensure there's only one instance of the image unless you deliberately want multiple.

📱 2. The image appears in both mobile and desktop layouts (e.g. grid + flex)

If you're using CSS like this:

css
display: flex;
flex-wrap: wrap;

Or:

css
display: grid;
grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr);

And then no media queries to adjust for mobile, it may look like images are stacked or doubled when space runs out.

✅ Fix: Add a mobile media query:

css
@media (max-width: 768px) {
  .portfolio-container {
    grid-template-columns: 1fr; /* Show one per row on mobile */
  }

  .home-img img {
    width: 100%;
  }
}

🧩 3. Positioning or visibility bug

Sometimes a hidden image (display: none) becomes visible in mobile due to a media query or JavaScript bug.

✅ Fix: Check for hidden duplicate image or mobile-specific CSS. For example:

css
.home-img {
  display: none; /* accidentally hidden on desktop */
}

@media (max-width: 768px) {
  .home-img {
    display: block; /* makes it reappear */
  }
}

🛠️ Want me to check your exact layout?

If you can tell me which section/image is duplicating (e.g., home image, about section, portfolio image), I can give you the exact fix. Or paste the mobile layout CSS and I’ll troubleshoot it line by line.

Thanks for sharing your full CSS. Based on this, here's why your image might be appearing twice on mobile:

✅ Likely Cause: Wrong selector used

In your CSS, you have this block under the mobile (max-width: 768px) media query:

css
.home-img img {
    width: 70vw;
    margin-top: 4rem;
    border-radius: 1rem;
    box-shadow: 0 0 20px var(--main-color);
}

But you don't actually have a .home-img img image selector outside this media query — meaning if your HTML looks like this:

html
<div class="home-img">
  <img src="your-image.jpg" alt="Home Image">
</div>

Then your desktop version only uses .home-img styling (not .home-img img), and the mobile version adds styles specifically to <img>. That’s fine.

However, you also have this earlier:

css
.home-img {
    width: 70vw;
    border-radius: 1rem;
    box-shadow: 0 0 20px var(--main-color);
    display: block;
}

And then in mobile, you add another set of styles directly to .home-img img. So what might be happening is:

  • You styled the parent .home-img, which might include a background image or an inline image (like a background-image or a duplicated <img>).

  • Then in mobile, you additionally style .home-img img, which might make an extra image appear, especially if there's both a background-image and an <img> inside .home-img.

✅ Check your HTML

Please look at your HTML section for the home image, and see if you accidentally did this:

html
<div class="home-img" style="background-image: url('image.jpg');">
  <img src="image.jpg" alt="">
</div>

If so, the background-image and the <img> will both be visible — and in desktop it might be hidden by layout, but in mobile where it stacks, it looks "duplicated."

✅ Solution

Make sure your image is only used once — either as a background or as an <img>, not both.

If you're using:

html
<div class="home-img">
  <img src="your-image.jpg" alt="">
</div>

Then in CSS, simplify it:

css
.home-img {
  width: 70vw;
  margin-top: 4rem;
}

.home-img img {
  width: 100%;
  border-radius: 1rem;
  box-shadow: 0 0 20px var(--main-color);
  display: block;
}

And remove any background-image or duplicate <img>.

✅ Optional fix: Add overflow: hidden or remove duplicated images

To avoid layout bugs from overflow:

css
.home-img {
  overflow: hidden;
}

If you'd like, paste your actual HTML for the image section (.home and .home-img), and I can spot the duplication exactly.

ChatGPT said:

It sounds like you're asking how to fix the issue of your image doubling or appearing twice when in mobile mode.

Here’s how to identify and solve it:

✅ 1. Check HTML: Are You Using the Image Twice?

Make sure you don’t have two <img> tags inside your .home-img section. For example:

html
<div class="home-img">
  <img src="your-image.jpg" alt="portfolio image">
</div>

If you accidentally have this:

html
<div class="home-img">
  <img src="your-image.jpg" alt="image">
  <img src="your-image.jpg" alt="image"> <!-- DELETE THIS -->
</div>

One of them should be removed.

✅ 2. Check CSS for ::before or ::after Image Content

Sometimes, an image might appear to duplicate because you're using something like:

css
.home-img::before {
  content: url('your-image.jpg'); /* This creates another image */
}

Make sure there's no content: url(...) in your CSS unless intentional.

✅ 3. Check Media Query (mobile section)

Inside your CSS, you have this:

css
.home-img img {
    width: 70vw;
    margin-top: 4rem;
    border-radius: 1rem;
    box-shadow: 0 0 20px var(--main-color);
}

That’s fine, but be sure you're not also duplicating .home-img img in your HTML or in other breakpoints.

✅ 4. Use Dev Tools

In your browser:

  • Right-click the image → Inspect

  • See if the image is rendered more than once.

  • If it is, track down where the duplicate <img> is coming from.

✅ Summary: Common Fix

If you only need one image:

html
<div class="home-img">
  <img src="your-image.jpg" alt="image">
</div>

And in CSS:

css
.home-img img {
  width: 70vw;
  border-radius: 1rem;
  box-shadow: 0 0 20px var(--main-color);
}

Make sure there's no second image, no ::before content, and no duplicate in your media queries.

In about section:

html

  • One image in the about section

  • They appear one after the other when stacked on small screens

✅ Option 1: Use only one image

If you don’t want to repeat the same image twice:

Use media queries to hide one image on smaller screens:

css
@media (max-width: 768px) {
  .about-img {
    display: none;
  }
}

This hides the about image on mobile.

Open Dev Tools (right-click → Inspect), go to "Elements", and scroll down to the about section to confirm both images are showing.

How to Add a Looping Background Video in Your About Section

You said:
i have problem i want the border of my image is always fitter on the image
ChatGPT said:

Gotcha! You want a border (or maybe a box shadow or outline) that always fits exactly around your image, no gaps or overflow.

Here’s how you can ensure the border fits perfectly around the image itself inside your .portfolio-box:

1. Add the border directly to the image, not the container

css
.portfolio-box img {
    width: 100%;
    display: block; /* Removes bottom whitespace */
    border-radius: 2rem; /* Same radius as container for consistent rounded corners */
    border: 0.2rem solid var(--main-color); /* Example border */
    box-sizing: border-box; /* Ensures border is inside image size */
}

2. If your .portfolio-box has overflow hidden and border-radius, match the image border-radius

css
.portfolio-box {
    border-radius: 2rem;
    overflow: hidden;
    position: relative;
    /* no border here if you want it on the image */
}

3. Optional: Remove padding/margin that causes border mismatch

Make sure you don’t have any padding or margin on .portfolio-box or the image that pushes the border away.

Why?

  • When you put border on the container, and the image inside is smaller or has padding, the border looks like it’s floating outside or not exactly around the image.

  • Putting border on the <img> with display: block and box-sizing: border-box fixes that.

Example snippet:

css
.portfolio-box {
    border-radius: 2rem;
    overflow: hidden;
    position: relative;
}

.portfolio-box img {
    width: 100%;
    display: block;
    border-radius: 2rem;
    border: 0.2rem solid var(--main-color);
    box-sizing: border-box;
}

Try this and tell me if it fits perfectly! If you want the border on the container for a different effect, I can help tweak that too.

You said:
when im in desktop mode the border of the image is bigger than the image which is bad when im in mobile mode it is good it fits the border with image it is in the home-img not portfolio box
ChatGPT said:

Thanks for clarifying! So the issue is in desktop mode inside .home-img where the border looks bigger than the image, but in mobile mode it fits well.

This usually happens because:

  • The image has some extra space around it (like margin, padding, or it's inline by default causing spacing).

  • Or the border is applied on a container, not directly on the image.

  • Or the image is not display: block, which can cause whitespace below it.

How to fix border sizing inside .home-img?

Here’s a common fix for that:

css
.home-img img {
    display: block;           /* Removes inline whitespace below image */
    width: 100%;             /* Make image fill its container */
    border-radius: 1rem;     /* Keep your rounded corners */
    border: 0.2rem solid var(--main-color);  /* Your border */
    box-sizing: border-box;  /* Border included inside width */
}

Make sure .home-img container doesn’t have padding that affects layout:

css
.home-img {
    width: 70vw;   /* or your desired width */
    border-radius: 1rem;
    overflow: hidden;  /* Keeps border-radius clipped */
    box-shadow: 0 0 20px var(--main-color);
    /* No padding or margin */
}

Why is it different on mobile?

In mobile mode, the image probably becomes smaller or the layout changes (like flex-direction: column), so the border looks correct.

On desktop, the image might have some default inline spacing or margin causing border overflow.

Also check:

  • No margin/padding on the <img> or .home-img container.

  • No conflicting styles applied by media queries.

Summary:

Put border directly on the <img> with display: block; box-sizing: border-box;, and remove padding/margin from container .home-img.

You said:
which one i will use in desktop mode?
ChatGPT said:

For desktop mode, you can use this CSS to make sure the border fits perfectly on the image inside .home-img:

css
.home-img {
    width: 70vw;                 /* or your preferred width */
    border-radius: 1rem;
    overflow: hidden;            /* to clip border-radius */
    box-shadow: 0 0 20px var(--main-color);
    /* no padding or margin */
}

.home-img img {
    display: block;              /* removes extra space below image */
    width: 100%;                /* image fills container */
    border-radius: 1rem;        /* same rounded corners */
    border: 0.2rem solid var(--main-color); /* your border */
    box-sizing: border-box;     /* includes border inside width */
    margin: 0;                  /* remove any default margin */
    padding: 0;                 /* remove any default padding */
}

Explanation:

  • .home-img sets the container size and clips the border radius.

  • The image inside is full width, block display (no inline spacing), with the border and radius matching the container.

  • box-sizing: border-box ensures the border is included inside the width, so no overflow.

If you want to keep it different for mobile, use media queries to override accordingly, but this CSS works well on desktop.

You said:
why it is become small to biiger as i change the resolution
ChatGPT said:

Great question! Here's why your image size changes when you resize the browser window:

  • width: 70vw; means the image container's width is 70% of the viewport width (vw = viewport width). So when you make the browser wider, 70% of that width becomes bigger — so the image grows.

  • When you shrink the browser, 70% of a smaller width means the image gets smaller.

This is why the image scales responsively based on the browser size.

If you want to control how much it grows or shrinks, you can:

  1. Use a max-width so it doesn’t get too big on large screens.

  2. Use a min-width so it doesn’t get too small on tiny screens.

Example:

css
.home-img {
  width: 70vw;       /* 70% of viewport width */
  max-width: 600px;  /* never bigger than 600px */
  min-width: 300px;  /* never smaller than 300px */
  border-radius: 1rem;
  overflow: hidden;
  box-shadow: 0 0 20px var(--main-color);
  margin: 0 auto;
}

This way:

  • When the screen is very wide, the image maxes out at 600px width.

  • When the screen is very narrow, the image won’t shrink below 300px.

  • Otherwise, it stays at 70% of the screen width.

Want me to help adjust it exactly to your needs?

  • playsinline keeps it playing inline on mobile devices.
